From the February 3, 1917 New York Times:
 
 
Relations With Germany Are Broken Off
 Break With Austria Too 
 Notice of Her Blockade Arrives as President is Speaking 
 EXPECTS NEUTRAL SUPPORT 
 President Expresses Belief That They Will Follow America's Course
 STILL HOPES AGAINST WAR 
 Mr. Wilson Unable to Believe That Germany Means to Carry Out Threat 
 Special to The New York Times 
 Washington, Feb. 3 -- Diplomatic relations between Germany and the United States were severed today. It was President Wilson's answer to the German notice that any merchant vessel which entered prescribed areas would be sunk without warning. Count von Bernstorff, the Kaiser's Ambassador, has received his passports, in other words, he has been dismissed by this Government. James W. Gerard, the American Ambassador at Berlin, has been ordered to return home with his staff. . . .
Those rascally German submarines sank a merchant ship from under my Swedish grandfather seacaptain in the Baltic Sea.
 
 Now, family legend has it that he lost not a man in the sinking of the ship BUT:
 
 HE LOST TWO SUITS OF HIS VERY BEST LONG UNDERWEAR!!!!

post_info.post_title: And, A Good Thing They Did

I don't get it emoticon_confused emoticon_confused What is your point? Are you tring to show that the past is the same as the present and the Germans at one time were as bad as the Iraqis today? Or is it just a funny old family story?

It was one of those "this happened a hundred years ago or so" stories that caught my eye.
 
 It has absolutely nothing to do with the present-day situation in Iran. Or anywhere in the Middle East.
 
 Although, one could argue that the roots of the present-day situation in the Middle East reside in the era I harkened back to, if not well before that time.
And there you have the Zen of History.
